subject: Move sensor collection to all sensors
commitMessage:
Move sensor collection to all sensors

Redfish's thinking on what sensors should be included in the sensor
collection has changed. Roughly two years ago their thinking was
"for sensors that are not covered elsewhere in the model-meaning do
not duplicate Power and Thermal" and that is what OpenBMC implemented.

Today, as described in the new thermalSubsystem and powerSubsystem doc
the sensor collection should contain all sensors that are associated
with that chassis.

Link with: https://redfishforum.com/thread/190/sensorcollection-contain-all-sensors-chassis

All things considered as "sensors" should be included in the Sensor
collection.

To make this transition as easy as possible for clients, create a new
meson option, new-powersubsystem-thermalsubsystem. This "all sensors in
the sensor collection" behavior as well as the new ThermalSubsystem,
PowerSubsystem, Fans, and Power Supplies schemas will be under this
option. This option is defaulted to disabled. At a later time, the
default will move to enabled.

Move Redfish SensorCollection to show all sensors from
/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors with the "all_sensors" association for that
chassis if this option is enabled.

The SensorCollection is found at /redfish/v1/Chassis/<Id>/Sensors.

Tested:
1. Enabled redfish-new-powersubsystem-thermalsubsystem and
   validator passes.

2. Performance testing (average of 5 times):
   a. Redfish validator time:
      without this patch: 71.375s
      with this patch:    71.763s

   b. Number of sensors tested:
      without this patch: 8
      with this patch:    63

   c. Run `https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Sensors`:
      without this patch: 0.197s
      with this patch:    0.228s

Signed-off-by: George Liu <liuxiwei@inspur.com>
Change-Id: I2bdddcf616dc72cf0683515c9ab8453bd35eee09

> Patch Set 13:
> 
> Does everyone has any comments?

Sorry, forgot to hit send on my one comment.

The core of why I haven't merged this yet is I'd like to better understand the new sensor schemas and how they relate to the thermal and Power schemas.  In a few mockups I've seen, the thermal and power schemas are now links, and I wonder if it would be better to do this in a single step, host all the sensors in the sensors collection, and add the links, all under a compile time option.  That seems like it would have the fewest question marks for compatibility, as I'm certain most implementations don't currently handle duplicated values well.

With that said, I'm still thinking, and have been busy with other reviews.

PS, the fastest way to get your code reviewed is to be reviewing others code in turn.

That seems like it would have the fewest question marks for compatibility, as I'm certain most implementations don't currently handle duplicated values well.
> 

I think this can and should stand on its own. 

There actually isn't a new sensor schema tied to this. 
Redfish's thinking on what should be in the sensor collection has just changed. 

https://redfishforum.com/thread/190/sensorcollection-contain-all-sensors-chassis

Clients (e.g. the webui) have a use case to show all the sensors.
This change means they can do this in 1 call per chassis vs 3. 

This new thinking of what the sensor collection is was drove by the new PowerSubsystem / ThermalSubsystem discussion as well as feedback but it isn't tied to the new PowerSubsystem / ThermalSubsystem. 

This was sent to the mailing list here: https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2021-January/024700.html

And it is has been on the mailing list before with disapproval of Redfish's "only part of the sensors". 

Why do we need a compile time option for the new PowerSubsystem and ThermalSubsystem ?
These can co-exist with the old. 

I know clients might get duplicate sensors but we have discussed this on the mailing list, I don't see how that is truly a break, and this long term is better.

> Redfish's thinking on what should be in the sensor collection has just changed.

> 
> Clients (e.g. the webui) have a use case to show all the sensors.
> This change means they can do this in 1 call per chassis vs 3. 

Yes, for this use case maybe it's faster, but for those that dump the entire tree, it's slower for no reason, as all of the thermal sensors and power sensors need to be pulled twice.  It also should be noted that we don't have filtering yet, so there's no way to just grab the sensor you want, which means the slower we make this, the more impact it has on things that want to read realtime sensor data. 

> 
> This new thinking of what the sensor collection is was drove by the new PowerSubsystem / ThermalSubsystem discussion as well as feedback but it isn't tied to the new PowerSubsystem / ThermalSubsystem. 
> 
> This was sent to the mailing list here: https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2021-January/024700.html

Yep I saw.  Thanks for doing that.

> 
> And it is has been on the mailing list before with disapproval of Redfish's "only part of the sensors". 
> 
> Why do we need a compile time option for the new PowerSubsystem and ThermalSubsystem ?
> These can co-exist with the old. 

I wasn't in the working group, but in the last slideshow I saw, the existing thermal and power schemas now had links back to the sensor collection?  How would we know to create those, and should they be mutually exclusive of the sensors for performance reasons?

> 
> I know clients might get duplicate sensors but we have discussed this on the mailing list, I don't see how that is truly a break, and this long term is better.

My worry is for the long term how do we get to the final solution, which in this case would be fully deprecating the existing power schemas and moving to the new form.  If we do this in 2 steps (first adding the new sensors, then deprecating the existing thermals), does this pose a worse problem for clients, because we arguably have to make two breaks instead of one?

This is a case where I really wish Redfish had a version flag that the client posted, so the client could ask for a specific deprecation version, and we could give them what they expect, but alas, that is not meant to be.

I will do my best to get to this research today.  I want to understand the implications of doing this to the redfish tree in terms of performance (how much slower is a full tree dump) and in terms of forward compatibility (what does fully deprecating the thermal schemas look like in the future).

I'm behind on this, so I apologize;  Way too many OpenBMC projects seem to have started at the beginning of the year and are now at the point of having patchsets.  I'm getting ahead of things.

If you had the numbers on how much slower this made a full tree dump, and the percentage increase in the time to list the sensor schema specifically, that would help.

Yes a link from select sensors to the sensor in the sensor collection. 
The ThermalMetrics / PowerSupply / Fan will only contain the current Reading of the sensor and a link to the Sensor in the Sensor collection so if you wanted to know more (thresholds, etc) you need to look at the Sensor Collection.

We need a design for how to select the "summary" sensors. I saw some chatter on discord about this. I think probably an association.

We aren't going to force clients to the new Power/Thermal schemas for probably a year or more. 
The new PowerSubsystem/ThermalSubsystem schemas are coming now. 
In the future there will be a deprecation message for the Old Power/Thermal schemas. 
After that, we will eventually turn off the old Power/Thermal schemas.

If we do this in 2 steps (first adding the new sensors, then deprecating the existing thermals), does this pose a worse problem for clients, because we arguably have to make two breaks instead of one?
> 
> We aren't going to force clients to the new Power/Thermal schemas for probably a year or more. 
> The new PowerSubsystem/ThermalSubsystem schemas are coming now. 
> In the future there will be a deprecation message for the Old Power/Thermal schemas. 
> After that, we will eventually turn off the old Power/Thermal schemas.


This kind of plan really needs documented in the commit message.  In terms of broad direction, I'm in agreement, and only really have questions on the details, but we need to write something down to give clients guidance on how to use this stuff and what to expect over the next year.

> 
> > 
> > This is a case where I really wish Redfish had a version flag that the client posted, so the client could ask for a specific deprecation version, and we could give them what they expect, but alas, that is not meant to be.
> 
> Why does that matter? Isn't a well behaved Redfish client supposed to walk the tree? I.e. use the new Schemas if they are there, if not use the old ? 

A well behaved redfish client is supposed to walk the tree, but it's also supposed to be able to assume that the location of similar data doesn't change implementation to implementation.  If we move to the new thermal subsystem schemas, that data effectively changes location, so old clients will break.  That's unfortunate, but unavoidable.

>

> > I will do my best to get to this research today.  I want to understand the implications of doing this to the redfish tree in terms of performance (how much slower is a full tree dump) and in terms of forward compatibility (what does fully deprecating the thermal schemas look like in the future).

> They gave a way and recommendation for how to transition. 
> 
> 1. Support both
> 2. Use the depreciate messages on the old power / thermal schemas 
> 3. Remove the old power / thermal schemas

The direction as discussed in discord: 

Separate options: 
meson option (this option) for the new (including all sensors) 
meson option (redfish-allow-deprecated-power-thermal) for the old 

until we get all support there / this year, the defaults look like:
disabled 
enabled

at a later date:
enabled
enabled 

at an even later date:
enabled
disabled

Quote the idea of @Gunnar:

```
Redfish's reply was "My statement from 18 months ago is no longer our 
recommendation. That was before we proposed to re-factor the Power and 
Thermal schemas to use the Sensor model. And that continues to be our 
direction. So in that light, we want everything that counts as a 
"sensor" to be part of the Sensor collection so that generic monitoring 
software can be built to harvest sensor data across the Redfish model.

Even if an implementation hasn't decided to adopt the (still a 
work-in-progress) PowerSubystem and ThermalSubsystem models, the 
underlying temperature and fan sensors can be rendered as Redfish Sensor 
resources as a good middle ground (and a step in the right direction for 
future work).".

Based on that reply, I propose we move Redfish SensorCollection to show 
all sensors. Let me know if anyone objects.

OpenBMC plans to support both the new and old Power/Thermal Schemas for some time. There does not appear to be a "new" sensor collection.
```
